newsitem.title: UK: Diet craze hits nine-year-olds, experts say.
newsitem.headline: Diet craze hits nine-year-olds, experts say.

text.p: The idea that thin means beautiful has filtered down to primary schools, with girls as young as nine starting diets, psychologists said on Friday.

But supermodels were not the role models for the dieting pre-adolescents. Instead, the girls were influenced by thin classmates, mothers who diet or even dolls, said Andrew Hill, a behavioural psychologist at the University of Leeds.
"Even by the age of nine there were girls who reported they were dieting," Hill told delegates at the British Association for the Advancement of Science's annual festival in Birmingham.
Hill, who has studied hundreds of young girls in his research, said this had nothing to do with actual weight.
"As has been found in adolescents, it was their perception of body shape rather than their actual weight that was at the root of their motivation to diet," he said.
Thin people are seen not only as more attractive but more intelligent and popular as well, he said.
"Fat is a modern, three-letter 'f' word," Hill told reporters. "It's something we are all disgusted at."
But Hill said the young girls were not getting their ideas from the emaciated catwalk beauties.

"She wants to be like the thinnest girl in her class," he said. Children whose mothers dieted were more aware of what dieting meant and toys also played a role. "Children's toys also reflect their changing experience of the world," he said.
Hill said Sindy dolls, originally made in the 1960s for young teenage girls, are now targeted at six to eight year olds.
"Sindy has lot her brunette bob, plain clothes and doll-like shape. She is now unashamedly blonde, pointedy thin (and) dressed immaculately to match," Hill said.

Boys also want different bodies, but only girls want to be thinner. In Hill's study of 400 nine-year-olds, boys preferred a body shape 12 percent heavier than their own average weight, while girls wished they weighed 11 percent less.
Such preferences can lead to eating disorders such as anorexia, when victims stave themselves, sometimes to death, in a vain attempt to control their lives.
Glen Waller of London's Royal Holloway College estimated anorexia affects up to one percent of young women and bulimia -- suffered by Princess Diana -- is seen in two to three percent.
